column4: It seems strange to me that Ubuntu would recognize my graphics drivers in the previous version, then mess up on them in the upgrade.
are you sure you have all the /meta/ - packages installed? a kernel update only works, if all teh related -restricted packages are updated as well
so what graphic card do you have, and which version of ubuntu do you run?

I do not know what graphic card I have, and I'm currently running edgy. I upgraded today from dapper. I think part of the problem may come from a power outage I had while the updater was running. I ran the updater, went to work, came back for lunch and the comp was dead.
how can I find out what graphics card I am running?
looks like GeForce 6100
so you expect that a half updated system, which was switched off during essential maintenace just works.... errrmmmm...
no, I don't. I continued all the downloads via update manager
so first do ' sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get -f install'  first, to get a defined stat
i ran those, and everything was updated
sudo apt-get install linux-restricted-modules-`uname -r` nvidia-glx && sudo nvidia-glx enable (note the backticks)
the apt-get install works, but the command 'nvidia-glx enable' doesn't
it tells you about 'wrong checksum' or something?
nah, I get 'command not found'
doesn't matter... just check in /etc/X11/xorg.conf in section drivers. it has to say 'nvidia' there, not nv
in xorg.conf, under the device for my video card, it's 'Generic Video Card' with 'vesa' as teh driver
ahhh..  ok, so you have to 'sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg' ... choose nvidia s the driver, not nv
once i run sudo nvidia-config, how soon should it take effect? Do I need to restart?
thanks! that did it!
have a nice day!
np :-)
